items.title: DAY 26 - BACK IN GERMANY
items.summary: Hirtshals - Fischerhude (599 km) The last but one leg…
items.content_html:
Hirtshals - Fischerhude (599 km)

The last but one leg takes me from the ferry port in Denmark back to the quaint little village near Bremen where I stayed on my way up. 

The day and a half I spend there before heading home are very atmospheric with mystic sunrises and sunsets. And blue skies and sunshine during the day. My little red friend and I do get a good workout on the nice cycle tracks. And on Saturday it really IS the last leg of my journey back to Neustadt. The total kilometer read upon arrival is 9.081.

items.title: DAY 24 - GOODBYE NORWAY
items.summary: Ringebu – Verdens Ende - Larvik (397 km) It’s the…
items.content_html:
Ringebu – Verdens Ende - Larvik  (397 km)

It’s the last day. And so it’s time to change the plan for the last time. My initial one to sleep in late and have a relaxed drive off to my ferry port of Larvik is out the window when I wake up at 4 am. So what to do? Find a place that I can visit to make use of the time. And I do find the “End of the World” (or, as they call it in Norwegian, “Verdens Ende”).

The drive is off the main E6 route and would be really scenic if I could see anything. The fog, very unfortunately, has decended upon my route, however, and so I have problems even spotting the car right in front of me.

Verdens Ende itself can be seen, but the mist hasn’t quite lifted yet as I get there. Only very grudgingly do the blue skies appear when I have to head off back to the road in the direction of Larvik. Never mind, I can easily overlook this slightly gloomy end as the whole trip has been so brilliant.

At 3.30 pm I am at the port, 2 hours before my departure to Denmark. And then it’s the final goodbye to Norway at 5.40 pm when the ship leaves port. Again on time. And in the sunshine.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 23 - SOUTHBOUND
items.summary: Toft – Ringebu (661 km, 1 ferry crossing) Another early…
items.content_html:
Toft – Ringebu (661 km, 1 ferry crossing)

Another early start. I get up at 5 am and sneak out of the house by 5.45 am to not wake Brigitta who still has got half an hour left of blissful slumber before getting up and heading for the airport. Because I have luggage to carry to the car, the sneaking is not through a window this time but through the back door. And then it is only me and my little red bike for the rest of the journey.

After the first stretch to my only ferry port for today, I can truthfully say that my moose-less days are over. And I now know that they are coming out around 6 am on a drizzly morning between Brønnøysund and Vennesund. In the dozens. Crossing roads. Eating trees in someone’s garden. Just being…well… moose, most likely. If that’s what they do. At least they have the decency to not run into my car. That would be truly annoying. And most likely more harmful to me and my car than to the moose. They ARE big buggers. Very long legs. And they look as if they are wearing high heels. Dressed to impress. That sort of thing.

The ferry arrives on time, as all ferries have done that we’ve taken over the past weeks. And I am setting off at 7.30 am on the other side on my still 610 km drive. Which is, indeed, very diverse and scenic. And very long. I arrive in Ringebu where I have booked myself a big whole house with 3 bedrooms (where are my fellow nymph-gnoms??? Why am I all by myself in such a big place???). I console myself by taking Brommy down from the rack and going on a short but very steep cycle ride up to the famous Ringebu Stavkirke with views across the town to the Kvitfjell skiing area.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 22 - KYSTRIKSVEIEN
items.summary: Sandnessjøen – Toft (79 km, 2 ferry crossings) Today we…
items.content_html:
Sandnessjøen – Toft (79 km, 2 ferry crossings)

Today we cover a short driving distance but have a bit of a waiting time at the ferry ports for our crossings. The day starts pretty gloomy with low hanging clouds. Nevertheless, we stop at a nice church soon after having set off and go for a little walk around a pretty little bay.

The first crossing is very scenic despite the clouds; and the drive to the second ferry port only takes about 15 minutes. By the time we reach that port, it has started to rain.

The second crossing takes less than 20 minutes, and the drive to our Rorbuer cabin another 30 minutes. We go for our last grocery shop on the way to buy some fresh stuff for tonight’s dinner.

By the time we have checked into our place, the sun has emerged. We head off, albeit in different directions. I have decided to do the Torghatten hike which was advertised as being a scenic 1.5 hour round trip through a whole in a rock. Brigitta has opted for checking out the immediate surroundings of our Rorbuer and observing the salmon of the farm (which is right in front of our window) jumping with joy in their enclave.

And then it’s good bye to togetherness and clinking a glass of wine to the great times we had.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 21 - KYSTRIKSVEIEN
items.summary: Glomfjord – Sandnessjøen (190 km, 3 ferry crossings) We set…
items.content_html:
Glomfjord – Sandnessjøen (190 km, 3 ferry crossings)

We set off at 08.30 am after a decent breakfast. The drive starts quite dramatic very quickly with views of the Svartissen glacier across the fjord. Our first ferry crossing is at 09.30 am followed by another shortish drive to the next ferry port. There we have to wait for over an hour for our next crossing, and take the time to go for a little walk.

The second ferry crossing takes us back across the Arctic Circle, and after an hour we have reached the mainland again. The following stretch of road is very scenic, indeed, and we decide to not rush it to the next ferry but rather go for another walk high above one of the fjords.

After the third and last crossing for today and a further drive of about half an hour, we reach our overnight stop, Sandnessjøen. What doesn’t look too appealing at first, turns out to be a rather nice little town, especially once you reach the outskirts with the harbour and views across the fjord to the Seven Sister mountain range.

Our day ends with a really delicious meal (fish again, what else?) in a nice Italian restaurant.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 20 - LEAVING LOFOTEN
items.summary: Sandoya – Glomfjord (470 km, 1 ferry crossing) The alarm…
items.content_html:
Sandoya – Glomfjord (470 km, 1 ferry crossing)

The alarm clock rings at 05.30 am and we are out of the house before 07.00 am. It’s quite a wet 2.5 hour drive to our first ferry stop in Lødingen. We are lucky to get the early ferry at 09.30 and arrive back on the mainland an hour later in Bognes.

The main highway E 6 takes us from Bognes to Fauske where we leave the main road to head for the famous Kystriksveien, the coastal road that runs almost 650 km from Bodø southwards to Steinkjer.

Our first stop is the Saltstraumen, the world’s strongest maelstrom where a huge volume of water forces its way through the 150-metre narrow strait in Saltstraumen four times a day, making enormous whirlpools that dance between the fjords. We are really lucky to get there right at the time where the tides are about to turn and the whirlpools are at their strongest.

The drive from there to our overnight stop at Glomfjord is another 2 hours with more stunning views along the route that are even more spectacular due to the rapidly changing weather from sunny to moody to rainy; all within minutes.

Our place for the night is...well….interesting. The little village of Glomfjord is mainly based around the Glomfjord hydroelectric power plant. Our (let's call it very basic) hotel has seen better days, but has a gym which is a welcome change for the muscles that haven’t been put to much use recently. And even though the restaurant doesn’t look very promising, their fish dishes are superb. And so we retire quite well fed and content at 09.30 pm.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 19 - LOFOTEN
items.summary: Friday the 13th. Horizontal rain. A perfect storm. Germans that…
items.content_html:
Friday the 13th. Horizontal rain. A perfect storm. Germans that go for a walk. Getting pissed on and pissed off. But still having fun. Somehow. Especially when coming back home into the warmth. And switching on the sauna. Kind of an appropriate end to a great week on Lofoten.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 18 - LOFOTEN
items.content_html:
Sandoya – Henningsvær – Stamsund – Mortsund – Leknes – Sandoya (163 km)

It’s time for a change of plans. Not that we had actually had a fixed one in our minds when we were considering to do Reinebringen again today. But the thought had been quite appealing yesterday. Not wanting to risk being greeted again by a sulky and foggy top, however, we decide to go the other direction to Henningsvær after having sent Julie off to Leknes airport for her flight back to the UK.

This time I manage to climb the top of Festvågtinden while Brigitta decides on the scenic opt-out version and stays at a little lake almost half-way. It’s a wise decision as the bit from the lake to the top isn’t for the faint-hearted. And the fact that the wind has picked up to gale-force gusts doesn’t help on the ridge with vertical drops.

Having survived the ordeal, and after being reunited with at least one of my fellow Nordic nymphs, we make our way down to the car and drive into Henningsvær, also known as the little Venice of the Lofoten as it consists of many small islands that are linked by bridges. It also praises itself to have one of the most famous football fields in the world. Check out the picture to know why.

We stock up on calories in the form of a nice coffee & cake stop, then set out on our scenic drive back via two small peninsulas to the Southwest of Leknes. In Leknes itself we have our first evening meal in a restaurant, then buy our last provisions for tomorrow and head back home. The sauna is a Must after this long day.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 17 - LOFOTEN
items.summary: Sandoya – Å – Sandoya (185 km) The day starts…
items.content_html:
Sandoya – Å – Sandoya (185 km)

The day starts very promising with blue skies and only patches of clouds. It continues like that on our drive down to the South of the Lofoten islands. It still looks ok-ish when we start our hike to the most famous Lofoten peak, the Reinebringen. And then….it all falls to pieces. Not in the wet way. But in the visual way. The fog is rolling in from the sea and decides to stay around the summit until we are back down at the car park. Now it has started raining. So we won’t want to go up again. What we do instead, is go to the famous Anita’s, a fish restaurant everyone recommends. And we don’t regret it. It’s pure heaven. Not only the fish. Also the desserts they have. If we were to have all we would like, we would need to climb Reinebringen at least another three times. Not today, though. Brigitta and I might come back tomorrow after sending Julie off to the airport. And only for one round. We think.

Back home we enjoy a beautiful sunset. Even the sheep have climbed the rock to admire the spectacle.

Click on the gallery then swipe or use ← → keys

items.title: DAY 16 - LOFOTEN
items.summary: Sandoya – Napp – Leknes – Sandoya (94 km) A…
items.content_html:
Sandoya – Napp – Leknes – Sandoya (94 km)

A rainy day. Girls do shopping. In the morning.

And go to The Grotta. In the afternoon.

And be given a tour of the Community Hall in Vestresand by Frode in the early evening. It's so interesting to hear all about the history of the place and how it's being run in present times. A really lovely end to a very different day.

And at the very end, the clouds start breaking up. Fingers crossed, the sun will be out again tomorrow.
